head.title: The Many Ways to Teach a Child

hedline.hl1: The Many Ways to Teach a Child

abstract.p: Arthur Eisenkraft letter responds to Robert B Reich's July 11 Op-ed article that criticized education system and standardized testing; rejects Reich's anti-intellectual and elitist position on science and math instruction (M)

block.p: While Robert B. Reich succeeds in describing some of the problems inherent in certain standardized tests (Op-Ed, July 11), he takes an anti-intellectual and elitist position on science and math instruction.

While Robert B. Reich succeeds in describing some of the problems inherent in certain standardized tests (Op-Ed, July 11), he takes an anti-intellectual and elitist position on science and math instruction.

Mr. Reich says that ''there's no reason that every child must master the sciences, algebra, geometry, biology or any of the rest of the standard high school curriculum.'' We could agree with Mr. Reich only if we saw no reason for the adults of the future to, for example, understand where their tax dollars are going (genetic engineering or space exploration), to discuss medical care with their doctors or to understand environmental issues like nuclear power or global warming.
ARTHUR EISENKRAFT President, National Science Teachers Association Arlington, Va., July 11, 2000
